TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit Panel extends System.Windows.Forms.ScrollableControl

Docs.summary: Used to group collections of controls.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A Panel is a control that contains other controls. You can use a Panel to group collections of controls such as a group of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.RadioButton> controls. As with other container controls such as the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.GroupBox> control, if the Panel control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Enabled%2A> property is set to `false`, the controls contained within the Panel will also be disabled.
The Panel control is displayed by default without any borders. You can provide a standard or three-dimensional border using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Panel.BorderStyle%2A> property to distinguish the area of the panel from other areas on the form. Because the Panel control derives from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollableControl> class, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollableControl.AutoScroll%2A> property to enable scroll bars in the Panel control. When the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollableControl.AutoScroll%2A> property is set to `true`, any controls located within the Panel (but outside of its visible region), can be scrolled to with the scroll bars provided.
The Panel control does not display a caption. If you need a control similar to a Panel that can display a caption, see the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.GroupBox> control.
## Examples The following code example creates a Panel control and adds a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Label> and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> to the Panel. The Panel control is displayed with a three-dimensional border to distinguish where the Panel control is located in relation to other objects on the form. This example requires that the method defined in this example is called from within an existing form and that the <xref:System.Drawing?displayProperty=fullName> namespace has been added to the source code for the form.
[!code-cs[Classic Panel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.windows.forms.p_16_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[Classic Panel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.windows.forms.p_16_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[Classic Panel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.windows.forms.p_16_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: public override bool AutoSize { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the control resizes based on its contents.
Docs.value: if the control automatically resizes based on its contents; otherwise, . The default is .

Docs.summary: Occurs when the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Panel.AutoSize%2A> property has changed.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the AutoSizeChanged event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=fullName> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=fullName> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Panel> named `Panel1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the AutoSizeChanged event.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#384](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/e-system.windows.forms.p_14_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#384](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/e-system.windows.forms.p_14_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Indicates the border style for the control.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks By default, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Panel> control is displayed without a border. You can use this property to distinguish the boundaries of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Panel> control from other areas on the form.
## Examples The following code example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Panel> control with a three-dimensional border.
[!code-cpp[Classic Panel.BorderStyle Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.windows.forms.p_13_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[Classic Panel.BorderStyle Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.p_13_1.vb)] [!code-cs[Classic Panel.BorderStyle Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.p_13_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnResize(class System.EventArgs eventargs) cil managed

Docs.param: An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.
Docs.summary: Fires the event indicating that the panel has been resized. Inheriting controls should use this in favor of actually listening to the event, but should still call to ensure that the event is fired for external listeners.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user can give the focus to this control using the TAB key.
Docs.value: if the user can give the focus to the control using the TAB key; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks When the user presses the TAB key, the input focus is set to the next control in the tab order. Controls with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.TabStop%2A> property value of `false` are not included in the collection of controls in the tab order. The tab order can be manipulated by setting the control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.TabIndex%2A> property value.
> [!NOTE] > The TabStop property has no effect on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Panel> control as it is a container object.
